title: Edinburgh’s Luxury Market Not Immune to Brexit Woes
text:
Luxury home prices in Edinburgh rose by a moderate 3.4% in the third quarter compared to a year ago, as Brexit uncertainty spreads to Scotland, according to an index from property consultancy Knight Frank on Tuesday.



Over the past two years, Edinburgh has remained one of the most robust prime housing markets in the U.K., even in the face of a looming Brexit. But the latest figures show that the Scottish capital isn’t totally immune to political turmoil in London.

Moderate growth in the third quarter marked a significant slowdown from a year ago, when luxury home values in Edinburgh were climbing at a heady 10.5% annual clip, according to market data from Knight Frank.



“Political rhetoric has ramped up in recent months, and has moderated price growth. So has a lack of urgency among some buyers,” said Oliver Knight, associate at Knight Frank.



Nevertheless, the city has outperformed the rest of the U.K. prime market, where home prices have fallen, on average, 1.7% compared to a year ago.



Edinburgh homes in the £1 million-to-£1.5 million (US$1.22 million to $1.83 million) range appreciated the most in the third quarter, with prices rising 5.4% in the year through September.

These days, price growth largely comes down to the city’s limited supply of luxury properties, a shortage that will continue to bolster home values in the city moving forward, the research team at Knight Frank predicts.



Would-be sellers are likely to become even more cautious, Knight Frank wrote, especially as “uncertainty surrounding Brexit mounts.”
